comments.commentBody:
.
.
This guy has some political ramifications, if you want to build a suitable bridge to the 21st century.

You don't see anyone like him writing in NYT.

Morning.

I like how the avatars are getting meta and phoric these days. You're turning into a real artist.
Martin, I've always been a real artist. You are just now getting it.

Martin, we were at a graduation party in the boonies for the Wife's grand niece and grand nephew, one from high school and the other from college. Came back and did the puzzle while watching Serena lose another major in her quest for a grand slam event and her 22nd major. Some of the best tennis I have seen...ever!

As for the puzzle, a real twister. Liked it.

No doubt that many will agree with your comment, so it bears reminding that there are Muslim countries where acid is NOT thrown on women for going to school. Just like in Christian cultures, there is a huge diversity of how Islam is interpreted and practiced around the world. In places like Turkey, Indonesia and Iran women are able to attain an education without any violence. So perhaps rather than branding an entire religion as the 'villain', maybe it's the radical interpretation of a religion by extremists that we should be looking at.
No, Islamic culture is primitive, misogynist, and violent. Everything else is just a matter of degree.
Islam is no more guilty than any and all male dominated superstition based belief sets (read religions.)

There is one heroine in this story and two villains. The heroine is Sultana whose name is perfect for a fairy tale. The villains are the Immigration Authority and Islam. I cannot believe that the governmental agency that lets a flood of undocumented labor into the country would put bureaucratic obstacles in the path of this girl. The trillions wasted in Afghanistan chasing Taliban would be much better spent on scholarships and online classes for women and men like her. The second villain is self-evident. The religion/culture that threatens a woman with acid because she wants to learn calculus is barbaric, savage and unworthy or respect. And yes, religion and culture are inseparable.
There were people who liked Nixon?

Kudos for Sultana. The Taliban is so retrograde, and so ignorant of the ways of the world, that Afghanistan must push to block these religious dogmatic thugs, hypocrites using the most advanced technology that education provides (witness the weaponry at their disposal, thanks to rich donors from Saudi Arabia, Catar, etc), and yet try to forbid and destroy their own people eager to learn and advance science and improve their own day-to-day lives. Radical Islam's return to the dark ages is a warning, that secular education is not carried out so their society may, one day, escape its dependency on others; instead, a free and proud people capable of deciding their own destiny.

There may also be a gender gap in medical care. Although women are more likely to seek medical care, they are also more likely to be under-diagnosed and under-treated for serious conditions. This could lead to higher death rates for women.
Maybe the advances in healthcare are missing some women who need them.

Great comment. Your primary residence is mainly an expense, not an investment. In my view, whether it is feasible trying to transform it into an investment is a matter of how much disposable income you have. If it isn't far above four figures, you'll probably be better off saving and maximizing your contributions to things like IRA accounts or 401k's. Basically, if your problem is not having to figure out how to invest a large disposable income, you probably should not think of buying a home; unless a truly good opportunity presents.

Homeowner insurance is expensive and there's a deductible.

HVAC and pest control is not covered by homeowners.

IMO condos in a retirement community are sometimes a reasonable choice.  When buying a condo, it's important that your circumstances are similar to those of your neighbors and are likely to be so long term.  For example, in growing areas, it's common for condos to be starter homes, and for people to move up when they have a kid or two.  That can mean that five years from now you'll be living in a rental community because the those moving up couldn't get their price.  It also means that the absentee owners are unwilling to pay increased common charges and maintenance becomes minimal.
Condos (or co-ops) are all many people would ever be able to afford, and even those can be a very difficult bar to clear, financially. A condo is the very best many people can do.
Excellent comment.

From the comments I've read, it seems that a lot of people see owning as too out-of-reach for many and too stressful and too much of a nuisance for others.  I remember a time when home ownership was done because people needed a place to live and families to raise.  It seems to me that this is no longer part of the American Dream.  I have put my co-op apartment up for sale because I just don't want to live in the same place that I have lived in for the past fourteen years.  I'm unattached and would like to experience a different part of the city.  And I agree with the others- owning really is a big headache, but I did enjoy the tax breaks, but off to a new adventure!
That depends on the rental market. If the cost of renting a 1 bedroom has tripled over the past 4 years and your income has not, it may be hard to move.
Another hidden cost of owning is that you will be tempted to make expensive renovations and redecorations that you would never have bothered with in a rented property.

When it comes time to repair the Miele range you may regret the choice.
And stay away from their dishwashers! Way more complicated than necessary.

Beware!  You may feel secure in your ability to move easily and affordably in Sacramento now, but San Franciscans are leaving to look for cheaper housing, and I know at least a few of them who are headed your way!  San Francisco and the entire Bay Area is so incredibly unaffordable right now, I'm sure Sacramento is bound to be affected in the not-so-distant future.
Northern CA as in the SF Bay Area is MORE expensive than Southern CA, including LA.
Buyers often overlook the eventual cost of selling which include a hefty realtor fee and months of mortgage payment between when you want to move and the sale closes

I'm not sure where you get your facts from, maybe Fox News, but the economy is in far better shape under President Obama then it was eight years ago when George Bush left office. Perhaps you should compare the unemployment rate released on Friday to what it was eight years ago. While there is still a long way to go, as many have not been helped by the recovery, we are in a far better place today then in 2008.

How unusual to include a former SOS as a responsible party to your laundry list of ills typically assigned to a president! But then, your statements are false!!! The ones doing the race-baiting, divisiveness, lawlessness, hating, ignorance and gross incompetence are the Congressional Republicans! They are the ones who hold the entire country hostage by refusing to do THEIR JOBS. The only thing Republicans have done in the past 8 years is to behave like spoiled, rich kids who can't find a way to not be held responsible for the crimes they've committed! Each time Obama has tried to compromise they refuse to negotiate in good faith, acting more like kindergartners who've not yet learned to share.

I have no idea what country or state of illusion you have been living in for the last 8 years, but it is decidedly NOT the same one I've been living in. After years of financial starvation under Bush, the VA was a mess. It IS getting better. I know this to be a fact! And it would be a whole lot further along in it's re-haul if Congress would appropriated the funds needed to do this!!!! But the Republican held congress refuses. They refused to obey the Constitution in doing their JOB to hold confirmation hearings to fill the supreme court vacancy!! As for the economy, Bush trashed it. Obama had to clean it up. He's done a fine job of that. Can you do better? Would it just be more trickle down economics which we ALL know doesn't work? Trump is unfit in every way to be president

John Brown:"Anyone wanting to see stupidity, hate, race baiting, divisiveness, ignorance, lawlessness, and gross incompetence need look no further than Obama and Hillary. After 8 years of Obama the Obama V.A. is still killing our veterans, and lines to get through airport security are far worse than they have ever been and getting worse, not to mention that Obama has given us the worst economic growth under any President since the Great Depression."  You are talking about the wrong period - that was the presidency of George Bush when the economy tanked - do you remember at the end of his presidency when the job market was shrinking by 800,000 jobs?????  President Obama has made heroic efforts, they had to be heroic because of the opposition he faced from the GOP who did not want Americans to recover so that he would not be re-elected.  How did that work out for you?  And you can blame those long lines at TSA on the GOP who hold the purse strings and have cut funding to allow increased staff to service the increased traffic at airports with the improved economy.  So, sure vote for Trump who will just blow up the whole world when he gets ticked off with Putin!!

Ignorance, stupidity and hate are universal human attributes.  Italians have them and Americans have them.  The biggest difference is that Americans make a lot more money off of these failings than the Italians do.  That's why we have Trump and that's why he is much more dangerous than Berlusconi.

I have lived in high cost markets (Washington, DC, Boston, and San Fran) over the last 25 years.  Renting has allowed me to save a LOT of money plus let me live in much nicer neighborhoods. Though I tend rent a smaller place then I would buy. This contributes to the ability to save. For something as large as a RE purchase if I were to buy again (did own before renting) I would buy only very blue chip type of place which comes at a premium. So again renting is  relative bargin.

RE:dealing with unresponsive cheapskate landlords
They attract cheapskate tenants. You don't get what you don't pay for.
Vanguard.

Not mentioned is the transaction cost of getting out of a house if one needs to move because of job loss or of an opportunity to take another job. It's around 10% of the value of the house to sell.

Something else not mentioned is that one tends to rent an apartment that is appropriately sized for one's current status. So a single person or young couple might rent a one or two bedroom apartment. But they buy a three bedroom house.

Buying a house is more of a lifestyle choice than an investment decision. It takes both time and money to maintain a home.

In the interests of full disclosure, I bought a house in the oil patch at the peak of the market at high interest rates just before oil prices collapsed (1981), and was underwater eight years later when I moved to take a new job. My rental income was less than my mortgage for the next eight years, at which point I sold for 5% more than I paid.

If you live in an area which restricts housing growth, your home is more likely to appreciate than if you live where housing is allowed to expand freely.

You typically pay about a 10% premium for new construction, and in two years your house will no longer be new construction.

If you buy a house with 5% down, you are 5% underwater if you have to sell shortly thereafter. If you buy new construction with 5% down, you're 15% underwater.

But you can't move every time someone else causes a problem. (Many condo buildings don't have larger units with many children, but it will be something else that bothers you.) Also, don't you have to break a lease in order to do this? A month-to-month lease isn't widely used, and often means the owner is trying to sell. Every dwelling place, both houses and multi-units, will have varying issues that you have to put up with, in my experience.
Kaleberg, did you include not needing to pay rent in your calculus of the investment value of a house?

"The lie here is that Hillary and all the other senators voted for the Iraq war."

Even Hillary has admitted that she voted for the Iraq War.

I'm not surprised to see reality denied and re-written in this way, but I am startled by the number of recommends it gets.

I guess that is what happens when you hold your nose so long and hard.
